DOC.brief_summary: This study seeks to assess the role of the GlideScope Ranger video laryngoscope in facilitating successful neonatal/pediatric intubation by pediatric critical care transport teams. The central hypothesis of this study is that the GlideScope Ranger video laryngoscope reduces the rates of failed intubation attempts by pediatric critical care transport teams. The aims of this project are designed to specifically: (1) Establish competencies for GlideScope Ranger video laryngoscopy-assisted intubation for pediatric and neonatal patients; and (2) Compare the intubation success rates for intubation using GlideScope Ranger video laryngoscopy and using conventional, direct laryngoscopy by pediatric and neonatal critical care transport teams.
DOC.brief_title: The Use of the GlideScope Ranger in Pediatric Critical Care Transport
DOC.criteria: age < 18 years Presence of respiratory failure requiring tracheal intubation by the Critical Care Transport Team either at the referring institution or during the transport to the receiving institution Ability of parent or legal guardian to provide written informed consent Patients 18+ years of age Patient has a functioning tracheostomy Patient does not require orotracheal intubation
